On Fri, 7 Nov 2003, Stirling, Scott wrote:

> > I think you're equivocating on the word 'class' here.
> > Classes are always dealt programmatically in Java via the
> > java.lang.Class object, or, if you're manipulating the
> > constituent binary data, via an InputStream or some other
> > object.  I think you were right before, in the general sense:
> > Java deals with objects except for the primitive types.
>
> Ha ha, reading my own words I noticed another equivocation.  I guess
> this is just a slippery area. :-)
>
> To be precise I should have said:
>
> > Classes are always dealt programmatically in Java via an
> > instance of the java.lang.Class class . . .

This is getting better.  Now I can see that you are saying that
classes are dealt with using an object, and therefore they _are_
that object.  Interesting.

May I submit that classes are dealt with using references, which are
themselves neither objects nor classes?  Oooo, this is tricky.

Part of the murkiness here is due to my peculiar experience: I know that
in reality Java at the JVM level is not a fully object-oriented language.
Certainly that Java has no difficulty in distinguishing classes from
instances of classes (and certainly it delights in gotos and other things
abominable to the OOPL community ;-)
